comments.commentBody: The stall as you calk it was in fact there are facts not presented while the news media tainted the public's mind...how often did the news media play the part where the boy's friend had told police he told Tamir he shouldn't have the gun there? How many times did the media show you how Tamir REALLY looked? Height AND weight??? How many times did you hear te 912 tlrelay call where the dispatcher told police what the 911 caller said about it being a boy with a toy gun? If the boy was smart enough to know to remove the orange safety then he knew he shouldn't point it at people...mind you I too am sorry he is dead but let's add the media to the pot for continuing to fuel racial tension...could the cops have taken more time before shooting? Maybe...

The boy was killed in Nov. of last year. It is now June, seven months later. The case is just now being handed over to the prosecutor. This is the decision phase where the prosecutor decides whether or not to file charges.

What do we know today that we didn't know two weeks after the child was shot? Why does it take seven months to complete an investigation where there is a video record and several eye witnesses? Of course the community leaders in Cleveland are distrustful of the justice system. They just endured a seven month stall of justice. Of course they are attempting to bypass prosecutors. Reference the seven month stall.

This has a very bad smell to it and the people are downwind of the stench. It smells of coverup.

The killer is a disgrace to any police force. By dragging out the so called investigation, the Cleveland justice system is refusing to acknowledge that shame, let alone correct it.

The bypass tactic is justified and necessary. The people of Cleveland know what they are up against.

I don't care WHAT the officer THOUGHT.   ANY cop who THINKS they may be threatened by an obviously toy gun in the hands of a child and who aggressively moves their car in so close and so fast that there is no time for OBSERVATION of the suspect, they are exhibiting extremely poor, rash judgment and are not the kind of person I want to pay with my tax dollars to "serve and protect" my fellow citizens.    I don't care what the cop THOUGHT.   It's what he DID that killed this kid.   At the VERY LEAST it's manslaughter, which is defined as:  "The unjustifiable, inexcusable, and intentional killing of a human being without deliberation, premeditation, and malice".

Not when kids are killing citizens and each other by the dozens. I can tell you now, if it doesn't have the orange muzzle, people, all people, better drop a gun on police command because nobody is guilty of of stopping a perceived deadly threat. You have a gun in your hand when they come on scene, you better surrender and allow then to reasonably sort things out. Drop the gun, stand still until they tell you otherwise.
All you have to do is watch the tape.

The cop who shot Tamir says he believed the gun was real and that Tamir was told to drop it 3 times.  The video shows Tamir occasionally pointing the gun at passersby.  The officer claims he shot Tamir because he thought he was a threat to others.  The issue isn't whether Tamir was such a threat.  It is whether the officer thought that he was such a threat.  Can you prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the officer is lying?  I can't.

@Wayne

Why, if GMOs are so necessary for feeding the human population of planet Earth, why is most of the GMO corn and soy produced in this country fed to animals? Wouldn't it be more efficient to feed the corn and soy directly to people?
Deadline, you are sorely needed.

The Civil War created a national ethos, with contrasting Northern and Southern components, which lasted until the late 1950s or early 1960s.  It was a world of railroads, Western Union telegraphs, newspapers with extra editions, world-leading industrial production, European immigrant waves, brilliant novelists, great popular culture, jazz, folk rebels like Woody Guthrie,  an optimistic and technologically leading people, and a horrible, entrenched system of discrimination against African-Americans, somewhat milder in the North and more severe in  the South.  With the Civil Rights revolution, the coming of the digital age, and a new inequality of income which puts the Gilded Age to shame, that nation now lives only in the past.

Prosecutors all over the country have abandoned their duty to enforce the law against police officers, assuming they ever took it seriously at all. No one who seeks justice in the hundreds of cases involving murder by police officers each year can trust prosecutors. The Garner case in New York was a particularly illustrative example of that reality. Prosecutors do not play it straight and do not care about the victims of these crimes or the law that says police officers, like everyone else, are not to take lives either intentionally or negligently without legal justification. There is no way that Tamir Rice posed a threat to a police officer's safety, so these people are right to ask a judge to recognize the reality that he was likely a homicide victim.

When I was a kid toy guns all looked like the real thing. If they didn't why would we play with them? In this case the kid was by himself in a park and the police raced their car up to him, jumped out and shot. The kid was by himself and obviously not a threat to anyone at that moment.
Thank heavens you are retired, Phil Z, if you would have reacted as the so-called officer did in murdering little Tamir. "Racially motivated vendetta against the police?" Oh, my sides!
This is good news.

The chart doesn't show the systematic degrading of our infrastructure or the starving of our school systems and basic research in the US. That massive change in priorities from creating growth to enriching the wealthy hasn't yet been felt by our society. The time frame where this has taken place is only 30 years and much of what was accomplished before this period has been carrying us. Please project the result of this new "trickle down" policy on our subsequent GDP's. I don't think we'll find as pretty as picture as what's shown here IMO.

Whether the police have a "tough and dangerous" job is not the issue. Police officers are obligated to obey the law. Too many don't and, instead, take lives with no reason or justification. Too many others lie for the murderers and yet too many more hide evidence to conceal officers' wrongdoing. Police officers, of all people, should be held to a standard of high ethical conduct. It is a sad reality that many officers, perhaps most, seem to care not at all about ethical behavior, even when it comes to respecting human life.
Why do you feel compelled to argue that protection by the police must involve a risk that the police kill the innocent?

Ah, there's the solution – arm the Kurds!

"Until the Kurds in the North are equipped with heavy weaponry....artillery, tracked vehicles, anti-tank weapons...[good things won't happen]."

Many people will think this is a very bad idea, likely to upset the governments of Iraq, Syria, Turkey, iran and [fill in the blank], which predictably will respond in kind, and so on and so on.

As luck would have it, though, I've managed to communicate today with the government of all countries that might be expected to object to this. To my surprise, they all had the same response: "Have the US supply heavy weapons to the Kurds? Sounds like a great idea! It's about time those long-suffering Kurds get a state of their own, and getting their hands on heavy weapons is the best way to accomplish that. Can we help out in any other way while we're at it -- maybe surrender some territory, send along some of our own heavy weapons, whatever? Just let us know, OK?"

Somehow "democratically elected" Putin claims that "there are no Russian troops" in Ukraine, but those troops keep being captured while killing Ukrainians on Ukrainian territory. If Russia is "supporting" terrorists with troops and weapons,  it is not a "civil war", it's a Russia-Ukraine war. Also, "democratically elected" Kremlin puppet Yanukovych does not even reside on the captured by the Russian forces land; he and his cronies reside in Russia with stolen cash, effectively betraying their voters.
First time, we made it with lobster - fabulous.  Second time we substituted monkfish for the lobster (and shrimp broth from leftover shells) and it was still delicious.
Well, if you'll be Frank, I will be earnest.  Be careful not to stub your kay in Detroit, Nathan.
I've been under the yum=yum tree, looking for you, Leapy.
AWW!

Down clues gave me TTLE and I discovered I was looking a gift horse in the mouth. I ended up running this mile in seven minutes.

Also...horsies!!!! :-D

Obama said it well --  Putin has to stop linking Russian greatness with taking the terrtitory of sovereign countries. Pretty basic.  He manages to keep popular support only by whipping the Russian public into an angry, fearful frenzy through his control  of TV through which he feeds his people a constant diet of distortions about what's going on in the Donbas region of Ukraine. It's criminal -- leads to war and death, and the G-7 is smarting up about this.

What I object to is people complaining about huge factory farms in the Midwest without providing any documentation. So I will provide you with some documentation. Please see: http://farm.ewg.org/top_recips.php?fips=00000&progcode=total
This site provides a list of all farm subsides paid by the Government from 1995 to 2012. If you spend the time to investigate you will find that of the largest 500 recipients, Iowa (a state in the Midwest) does not appear one time where as Mississippi (a Southern state) by itself appears 127 times. The huge crop growing farms are not found in the Midwest as you have claimed, but rather are mostly located in the South, plus Texas, Arizona, and California.
I am sure they know they were raided.
Members of Islamic State are not "civilians employees of a government". What government?

ISIS is not an institution that's fighting for the freedom of people. The group is expanding killing their own brothers and sisters (figuratively speaking) and people who have religions that is not the same as their's. They were not oppressed for their religion or anything though Western involvement is key in their existence. I am just trying to make the point that people running amok and invading other territories and killing others for absurd reasons are not freedom fighters. It might even be wrong to stop with the word "terrorists."
Awesome. Thank you all for the team effort. It was a delightful surprise and really appreciated. What a nice tribute to the magnificent Triple Crown winner and fun solve for us.

killing each other wish us weapons... sorry, the blood can not be washed from the hands of the US, in particular the neocons, who wanted preciselt to happen what has happened - to benefit Israel. Period.

And they wrote *policy* papers about it, so spare me the smears.
